ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course provides nuanced insight into the Middle East and the social issues that riddle the region. Professor Pepi also provided us with key anthropological tools.

We learned a lot about orientalism, anthropological approaches, Foucault, the politics of history, nationalism in different countries, collective resistance, and counternarratives to the stereotypes of queer and gender expressions in the region.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a very reading heavy course, but the insights you get from those readings are extremely valuable. I recommend taking this course after having general knowledge about the Middle East to understand the terminology used in the readings and in the discussion.

Maybe it's due to the fact that we had such a small class this year (less than 10 students), but I truly think one of the strengths was the class size. It allowed us to get close and build rapport, which facilitated the partner presentations.
I also loved the guest speakers that Professor Pepi invited. We read their work and had time in class to prepare questions before meeting them, and the experience was really rewarding as we even had access to chapters of work that had yet to be published.
I think the only weakness is that we didn't get to talk about the sci-fi films as much as I wanted to. This was less the fault of the instructor, and more an issue with scheduling, as that discussion was saved for the last day of class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything was remote, so in regards to safety and accessibility, this course was successful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. Professor Pepi is so knowledgeable about the Middle East and facilitates a great discussion. She also created an amazing syllabus, where the readings are able to interact with each other. Our class dynamic fit very well, and even in a Zoom format, I felt so welcomed. The course is honestly life-changing and is essential for anyone studying the Middle East.

YES! I think there are a lot of misconceptions about the MENA region, and this class really opened my mind, arguing that singular histories are a political project to maintain power structures. While the reading load is intense, the course is structured to make it very manageable, and the writing assignments serve to allow us space to critically flush out ideas, rather than regurgitate summaries. It was probably my favorite class this semester. I wish it was cross-listed as an ER&M course; the syllabus matches well with major themes in the ER&M department!
